I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
programmatic approach for the Recovery through Improved Systems and Expenditure Support 
Program, and (ii) proposed policy-based loans to the Republic of Palau for subprogram 1 of the 
Recovery through Improved Systems and Expenditure Support Program.1 
 
2. 
The program comprises two subprograms supporting public sector management reforms 
that will facilitate  Palau’s recovery from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) crisis. It  seeks to 
strengthen  public  financial  management  (PFM),  reduce  fiscal  risks,  and  support  private  sector 
development toward restoring sustained and equitable economic growth. The program will also 
provide further support for Palau’s COVID-19 mitigation measures—initially supported under the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) Health Expenditure and Livelihoods Support Program—with the 
availability of assistance having been extended beyond January 2021 (para. 5).2 The program is 
aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priorities  of  strengthening  governance  and 
institutional capacity, including a differentiated approach to institutional strengthening and private 
sector  development  in  small  island  developing  states  (para.  9),  and  accelerating  progress  in 
gender equality.3 It is also consistent with the Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 strategic priorities of 
managing risks by promoting sound public sector management and reducing costs by creating a 
more enabling business environment, as well as with the proposed Pacific Approach 2021–2025.4 
 

II. 

PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 

Background and Development Constraints 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Development context. Palau is a small island developing state with a population of about 
18,600 (as of 2019) and a land area of 458 square kilometers. It is the most vulnerable economy 
globally,  based  on  the  United  Nations’  Economic  Vulnerability  Index. 5 Recent  shocks  include 
typhoons Bopha in 2012 and Haiyan in 2013, a drought in 2016, and COVID-19 impacts in 2020. 
Palau receives grants averaging 9.7% of gross domestic product (GDP) through its Compact of 
Free Association with the United States. Although Palau is classified a high-income economy with 
nominal per capita gross national income of $16,490 in 2019, elevated cost structures stemming 
from its remoteness and small domestic market erode purchasing power.6  
 
4. 
Tourism-driven economy hit hard by COVID-19. With annual tourism receipts reaching 
the  equivalent  of  36.5%–53.4%  of  GDP  during  FY2010–FY2019,  Palau  is  among  the  most 
tourism-driven economies globally. However, the tourism industry has struggled since FY2016. 
From  a  peak  of  nearly  170,000  tourists  in  FY2015,  arrivals  declined  to  less  than  90,000  in 
FY2019.7 The drop was initiated by a drought that affected water supply in hotels and resorts,

flight services because of weak demand. Amid COVID-19 travel restrictions, arrivals fell by 53% 
to below 42,000 in FY2020 and could plunge to less than 10,000—mostly essential travelers and 
returning  residents—if  travel  remains  restricted  until  end-FY2021.  Because  of  this  prolonged 
tourism downturn, Palau had seen successive economic contractions during FY2016–FY2019, 
except  for  FY2018  when  the  economy  was  boosted  by  the  advent  of  high-speed  internet 
services.8 Early assessments projected economic contractions of 9.5% in FY2020 and 12.8% in 
FY2021.9 The latest assessment of the  International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates a deeper 
contraction of 10.3% in FY2020, with a further 7.8% decline projected for FY2021.10 However, the 
early commencement of COVID-19 vaccination in Palau provides an upside to the outlook.11 
 
5. 
Reversal  from  fiscal  surpluses  to  near-term  deficits.  Even  amid  its  pre-pandemic 
economic downturn, Palau demonstrated solid fiscal management by maintaining annual fiscal 
surpluses averaging 3.0% of GDP during FY2011–FY2019 (footnotes 9, 10, and 12). However, 
because of COVID-19 impacts on economic activity, tax collection declined by 25% in FY2020 
and another 24% drop is expected in FY2021.12 With $20 million in additional spending to mitigate 
adverse impacts on the private sector authorized under the Coronavirus Relief One-Stop Shop 
(CROSS)  Program,  the  IMF  estimates  that  a  fiscal  deficit  equivalent  to  11.2%  of  GDP  was 
recorded in FY2020.13 Another $12 million will be needed to extend CROSS assistance measures 
until the end of FY2021, which could push the deficit to 15.7% of GDP during this fiscal year.14 

 
6. 
Sound  macroeconomic  management  underpins  positive  outlook.  Robust  macro-
fiscal management, which helped achieve surpluses before the COVID-19 shock, can facilitate a 
return  to  a  positive  fiscal  position  over  the  medium  term  when  growth  resumes  in  Palau.  On 
revenues, reforms to raise tobacco taxes and departure taxes pushed the tax–GDP ratio up to an 
average of 20.2% in FY2015–FY2019 from 17.3% in FY2005–FY2014. Similarly, on expenditures, 
Palau has successfully controlled the public sector wage bill, which declined as a share of GDP 
to an average of 14.7% during FY2015–FY2019 from 17.1% during FY2005–FY2014. The IMF 
recognizes  Palau’s  record  of  fiscal  prudence,  which  led  to  a  buildup  of  government  deposits 
(footnote 10). The government saved the bulk of FY2011–FY2019 fiscal surpluses, which resulted 
in the general fund reserve rising to 11.2% of GDP in FY2019.15 In line with the IMF’s projections, 
ADB expects the fiscal deficit to fall to 14.4% in FY2022 as growth resumes, and the government 
pursues  expenditure  consolidation  measures  (including  controlling  recurrent  expenditures). 16 
Public debt is also projected to be sustainable (para. 27).

Lack  of  a  medium-term  outlook.  Palau’s  budget  is  missing  a  multiyear 
perspective,  with  fiscal  policy  only  required  to  adhere  to  a  legal  requirement  of 
maintaining at least a balanced budget for spending financed through the general 
fund.  Although  a  medium-term  fiscal  strategy  (MTFS)  was  prepared  with  ADB 
technical assistance (TA), this requires updating given COVID-19 pressures.18 
Outdated and inefficient tax regime. Palau’s tax system relies heavily on gross 
revenue  taxes  and  import  duties,  which  together  account  for  half  of  annual 
collections.  This  system  is  inefficient  and  distortionary,  and  discourages  private 
investment. During FY2015–FY2019, Palau’s tax–GDP ratio was 20.2%, below the 
24.4%–29.0% range for other tourism-driven Pacific economies. 
Significant transfers to  state-owned enterprises  and social security funds. 
With tariffs set below full cost recovery, Palau Public Utilities Corporation (PPUC) 
required subsidies averaging $1.5 million (2.3% of recurrent spending) in 5 of the 
7  years  from  FY2013  to  FY2019. 19 Further,  in  FY2019,  Palau’s  social  security 
funds  received  transfers  totaling  $3.7  million  (3.4%  of  recurrent  spending)  and 
needs are projected to rise because of substantial unfunded liabilities. 

 
Weak  business  environment.  Although  Palau’s  private  sector  contributes  about  two-
8. 
thirds of annual GDP, weak legal frameworks contribute to low investment—private sector credit 
was  only  11.9%  of  GDP  during  FY2015–FY2019—and  constrain  growth  in  business  and 
employment  opportunities.  The  absence  of  unified  rules  and  procedures  for  international 
commercial  arbitration  discourages  cross-border  investment  because  of  perceived  risks  from 
domestic dispute resolution mechanisms. Palau’s corporations legislation is also outdated, still 
requiring  incorporators  to  appear  before  a  clerk  of  the  Supreme  Court  or  a  notary  to  sign 
application documents, for approval by the President of Palau.20 Further, the absence of a modern 
electronic  corporations  registry  leads  to  information  gaps  that  can  be  exploited  by  beneficial 
owners of companies for tax avoidance or evasion and for possible money laundering. Moreover, 
a framework for public–private partnerships (PPPs) is absent. In April 2019, Palau entered its first 
PPP arrangement—for the upgrading and management of a new international airport terminal—
facilitated  by  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency.  With  more  PPPs  expected  in  the 
medium term, including in renewable energy generation, a formal PPP framework will be needed 
to  guide  the  selection,  monitoring,  and  regulation  of  private  sector  partners  to  minimize  the 
potential for incurring new contingent liabilities that would add to the government’s debt burden. 
The government plans to encourage PPPs to expand the revenue base for tax collections. 
 
9. 
Reform context. A differentiated approach to supporting public sector reforms is needed 
in  small  island  developing  states  constrained  by  limited  capacity,  including  Palau.  For  policy-
based operations, this involves using a programmatic approach with initial actions that  lay the 
foundation for more substantive reforms, interim milestones to sustain momentum and maintain 
the government’s focus on reform outputs, broad-based engagement while building capacity for 
deeper reforms, and integration with ADB country activities to reinforce results achievement.21

3 

 

 Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 

Lessons.  Previous  ADB  policy-based  operations  in  Palau  demonstrated  the  need  for 
10. 
(i) parallel TA to supplement the reform design and implementation capacities in key government 
agencies,  and  (ii)  sustained  consultations  with  stakeholders  to  mitigate  risks  of  reform  delays 
amid  changes  in  political  leadership.22 Further,  lessons  from  ADB’s  implementation  of  Pacific 
budget support programs during the 2008–2009 global crisis highlight the critical need to support 
aggregate demand, while protecting the fiscal position through well-targeted stimulus packages.23 
 
B. 
 
11. 
Program  description.  The  government  recognizes  the  need  for  complementary  policy 
reforms to safeguard fiscal sustainability amid the COVID-19 crisis. This is demonstrated in its 
commitment to (i) implement its MTFS, (ii) adopt a fiscal responsibility act (FRA), and (iii) restart 
the tax reform process, as expressed in the June 2020 development policy letter for the Health 
Expenditure  and  Livelihoods  Support  Program  (footnote  2).  A  policy-based  loan  is  a  suitable 
modality  to  support  the  government’s  wide-ranging  reform  agenda.  A  programmatic  approach 
allows  for  the  prioritization  and  sequencing  of  policy  actions—to  account  for  implementation 
capacity constraints—while bridging budget support needs to sustain reform momentum. It also 
provides the flexibility to adapt the reform agenda to emerging opportunities and constraints. 
 
12. 
The program aligns with the  government’s  reform agenda to safeguard Palau’s  longer-
term  fiscal  sustainability  (para.  11).  Both  subprograms  will  support  reforms  in  three  areas: 
(i)  the  policy  and  legislative  framework  for  PFM  strengthened;  (ii)  fiscal  risks  from  weak 
management  of  public  revenue,  expenditure,  and  liabilities  reduced;  and  (iii)  private  sector 
development  supported  (Appendix  4).  Subprogram  1  lays  the  foundation  for  improving  fiscal 
sustainability  through  the  introduction  of  upgraded  policy  frameworks,  guidelines,  and  plans 
(paras. 15 and 17); the approval of comprehensive reviews and evaluations, with recommended 
reforms (paras. 19 and 20); and the preparation and President’s transmittal of critical legislative 
bills to Palau’s National Congress (Olbiil Era Kelulau [OEK]) for approval (paras. 14, 16, 18, and 
20). Subprogram 2 will build on this foundation by starting to implement refined guidelines and 
plans; adopting reform recommendations from reviews and evaluations; and institutionalizing key 
reforms. The program seeks to include strong reform actions by the government. However, it is 
also important to ensure that reforms move forward steadily with attention to the achievement of 
medium-term  objectives.  To  promote  this,  the  program  includes  a  critical  administrative  action 
that sets a high-level direction to initiate the strengthening of the legal and regulatory framework 
for PPPs, which will facilitate increased  private sector participation in public service delivery.24 
Reform  targets  account  for  implementation  capacity  constraints,  given  Palau’s  small  public 
administration (para. 9). 
 
13. 
Under subprogram 1, ADB supports 10 prior actions, all of which have been completed. 
Ten  indicative  triggers  have  been  identified  for  subprogram  2,  for  refinement  based  on 
government priorities and capacity, considering possible continued COVID-19 disruptions. 
 
14. 
Reform area 1: Policy and legislative framework for public financial management 
strengthened.  Subprogram  1  supports  the  development  of  a  bill  that  sets  out  the  FRA,  with

 provisions for managing public revenue, expenditure, debt, and fiscal buffers. The FRA includes 
provisions to be reflected in annual national budgets, for (i) maintaining operating expenditures 
within medium-term targets; (ii) prioritizing capital spending to upgrade public assets over time; 
(iii) maintaining debt at prudent levels; (iv) preserving the real value of Palau’s Compact Trust 
Fund (footnote 17) by establishing investment and withdrawal rules; (v) adopting a modern and 
efficient tax regime suitable for a tourism-based economy; (vi) managing reserves as insurance 
coverage for cyclical downturns, disasters, and climate change impacts; and (vii) managing fiscal 
risks  from  public  sector  entities,  including  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  and  social  security 
funds. The President has transmitted the bill to the OEK for approval. The FRA prescribes a strict 
process  for  departure  from  these  provisions  to  allow  for  flexibility  during  fiscal  shocks.  The 
government  may  deviate  from  FRA  provisions  provided  that  the  departure  is  temporary,  with 
reasonable justification and specification of a clear period after which fiscal policy must revert to 
adherence  to  FRA  provisions.  Subprogram  2  will  commence  the  implementation  of  FRA 
provisions, starting with the inclusion of a new economic and fiscal update section to underpin the 
FY2022 budget. This section will provide a detailed assessment of how the government’s fiscal 
program adheres to specific FRA provisions toward safeguarding fiscal sustainability. 
 
15. 
Subprogram  1  also  supports  the  preparation  of  MTFS  guidelines  that  adhere  to  FRA 
provisions, which were issued as a presidential directive. The implementation of the guidelines 
will  begin  under  subprogram  2  through  the  presentation  of  an  MTFS  that  applies  a  multiyear 
budgeting  approach  in  the  FY2022  budget.  The  MTFS  will  be  refined  annually  to  reflect  the 
prevailing macro-fiscal context. Annual budget statements will supplement and update the MTFS. 
 
16. 
Reform area 2: Fiscal risks from weak management of public revenue, expenditure, 
and  liabilities  reduced.  Since  COVID-19  requires  substantial  borrowing,  greater  domestic 
resource  mobilization,  more  efficient  public  spending,  and  improved  debt  management  are 
needed to create sufficient fiscal space to service debt. Subprogram 1 supports the design and 
development of a tax reform package that (i) broadens the revenue base by replacing the general 
imports  tax  with  a  value-added  tax  that  brings  consumption  of  services  into  the  tax  net, 
(ii) eliminates distortions by moving from gross revenue taxation to a net profits tax and replacing 
import  duties  for  alcohol  and  tobacco  with  an  excise  tax  that  also  applies  to  local  production, 
(iii) promotes equity by adjusting income thresholds for the wages and salaries tax and aligning 
the net profits tax with the highest marginal tax rates for wages and salaries, and (iv) includes 
actions to help remove barriers to businesses owned by women. The President has transmitted 
the tax reform package to the OEK for approval. Under subprogram 2, a tax reform committee 
will be established and operationalized by the Ministry of Finance (MOF), with at least 30% female 
staff, to oversee tax reform implementation, including the development of implementing rules and 
regulations and the identification of systems upgrading and capacity-building needs. 
 
17. 
On  expenditures,  subprogram  1  supports  the  MOF  in  (i)  adopting  public  expenditure 
reprioritization measures during FY2021, including adjustments to the targeting and delivery of 
COVID-19 assistance, based on recommendations from the FY2020 Economic and Fiscal Review, 
the  first  of  regular  evaluations  of  budget  execution  amid  the  pandemic;  and  (ii)  preparing  and 
endorsing a climate-resilient and gender-sensitive national infrastructure investment plan (NIIP), 
prioritizing timely upgrades to and adequate maintenance of existing assets. The NIIP supports 
the FRA provision of prioritizing capital expenditures to ensure an increase in national net worth. 
Subprogram  2  aims  for  the  implementation  of  the  NIIP,  as  reflected  in  annual  capital  budgets 
starting in FY2022. Expenditure reprioritization will continue in FY2022 (and beyond, potentially 
supported  by  a  post-program  partnership  framework  [para.  28],  as  needed),  informed  by  a 
successive review of evolving COVID-19 impacts and relief measures (footnote 14).

 Subprogram  1  supports  the  development  of  a  bill  for  an  external  debt  management 
18. 
framework, with provisions for strengthening the review of the fiscal and economic implications of 
new borrowing, while improving debt transparency. The framework requires the creation of a debt 
management  unit  responsible  for  the  technical  due  diligence  and  debt  sustainability  analysis 
(DSA) of any proposed borrowing. The President has transmitted the bill to the OEK for approval. 
Under  subprogram  2,  the  MOF  will  issue  a  debt  management  policy  that  supports  the

19.

legislative action on unfunded benefits. Subprogram 2 targets the transmittal by the President of

Reform  area  3:  Private  sector  development  supported.  The  program  supports 
broadening  the  revenue  base  through  expanded  business  opportunities,  which  are  critical  for

arbitration bill to be approved by the OEK and signed into law, as well as the President’s issuance 
of a PPP framework and transmittal to the OEK for the approval of an updated Corporations Bill.

Given the change in political leadership in January 2021, following the November 2020 
elections, ADB consulted closely with both the outgoing and incoming administrations to ensure

Development partner coordination.  The program was developed in coordination with 
23. 
the  IMF  to  help  safeguard  macroeconomic  stability  during  the  COVID-19  crisis.  TA  from  the 
PFTAC helped the government to assess options for making the tax system more efficient and 
equitable, including an impact analysis of the potential introduction of value-added tax. This led 
to  the  development  of  the  tax  reform  package,  which  is  supported  under  reform  area  2  of  the 
program  (para.  16).  The  PFTAC  is  supporting  parallel  tax  administration  reforms,  including 
systems strengthening for on-time filing and payment as well as the management of tax arrears.30 
An IMF assessment letter was received by ADB in January 2021. The government is engaging 
with other partners, including the World Bank and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, 
for possible budget support. ADB is in regular dialogue with these development partners. 
 
C. 
 
24. 
The reforms will shift Palau’s economic recovery from the COVID-19 crisis toward a more 
sustainable  fiscal  path.  A  strengthened  policy  and  legislative  framework  for  PFM  will  support 
fiscally responsible and strategic budgeting toward efficient allocation of government resources. 
By reducing fiscal risks and improving the management of public revenue and expenditure, the 
government can generate fiscal space for more productive spending to support recovery. Further 
private sector development will help broaden the economic and revenue bases, which, in turn, 
will contribute to longer-term fiscal sustainability. The impact that the program is aligned with is 
enhanced quality of life for current and future generations of Palauans.31 The subprogram reforms 
will contribute to this through sequenced policy actions (paras. 14–20). The program is expected 
to help reduce the fiscal deficit to 5.5% of GDP or less (from 14.4% of GDP projected in FY2022), 
and raise the tax–GDP ratio to above the pre–COVID-19 average of 20.2% by FY2023. Further, 
the implementation of reforms of both revenue and expenditure will help the government generate 
sufficient fiscal space to service higher debt levels arising from the COVID-19 crisis.32

25.

needs  significantly,  as  reflected  in  projected  fiscal  deficits  of  $37.1  million  (15.7%  of  GDP)  in 
FY2021 and $37.9 million (14.4% of GDP) in FY2022 (Table 1). Based on these substantial needs, 
the  government  has  requested  program  financing  of  $55  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources. The proposed financing will be disbursed in two subprograms—$25 million in FY2021 
and $30 million in FY2022. Along with the program supporting PPUC reforms (footnote 19), ADB’s 
budget support will total $30 million in FY2021 and $35 million in FY2022.

27. 
Debt sustainability. Palau’s public debt is mostly external, with domestic debt equivalent 
to 7.0% of GDP as of FY2019. External public debt fell gradually from 38.3% of GDP in FY2009 
to 23.1% in FY2015, before a rise to 31.1% in FY2019 amid infrastructure investments supported 
by ADB.33 The onset of the COVID-19 crisis pushed Palau’s public debt–GDP ratio to 57.7% in 
FY2020. Although a further rise in public debt–GDP to 70.9% in FY2021 and a peak of 74.4% in 
FY2022 is projected, ADB’s updated DSA shows that debt will maintain a steady downward trend 
in the medium term as the economy recovers (footnote 16). With sustained recovery, the public 
debt–GDP ratio can revert below the pre-COVID-19 level by FY2030, even under conservative 
economic  growth  assumptions.  Further,  while  total  projected  borrowing  during  FY2021  and 
FY2022 will add to debt service obligations, the complementary implementation of fiscal reforms 
can ensure sufficient resources for annual repayments. Program support to contain fiscal risks 
from SOEs and the social security pension fund will also help ensure that contingent liabilities are 
minimized. ADB’s DSA concludes that Palau’s debt remains sustainable and fiscal vulnerabilities 
are contained. These results align with the conclusions of the IMF (footnote 10).

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 
29. 
Governance. Palau has a strong recent record of sound fiscal management, as exhibited 
by the achievement of annual fiscal surpluses since FY2011, but the IMF points to broader PFM 
aspects that need to be improved over the medium term (para. 7). Although a public expenditure 
and financial accountability (PEFA) self-assessment was conducted in 2013, the results are not 
publicly available and a planned follow-on formal assessment has been delayed. The PFTAC is 
preparing  to  conduct  a  streamlined  or  AgilePEFA,  along  with  pilot-testing  of  a  PEFA  climate 
module, as indicated in its FY2021 work plan for Palau (footnote 30). These assessments, which 
should lead to a formal PEFA assessment, will be critical to identify further actions for inclusion in 
an  updated  PFM  reform  plan.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was 
explained to and discussed with the government. 
 
30. 
Poverty and inequality. With per capita incomes at risk of falling to pre-FY2001 levels in 
real terms, basic needs poverty could rise from 19.4% of Palau’s population in 2014 to 26.5% by 
the end of FY2021.35 A strengthened policy and legislative framework for PFM will allow more 
strategic fiscal planning for efficient allocation of public finances. Reduced fiscal risks from the 
management of public revenue, expenditure, and liabilities will create additional fiscal space that 
can be harnessed to increase productive public spending, including for basic services and social 
protection. Private sector development will result in expanded income-generating opportunities. 
 
31. 
Gender. The program is classified some gender elements. It ensures more resources in 
the short term to support disadvantaged groups against COVID-19 crisis impacts and to preserve 
recent  gender  equality  gains.  Actions  to  reduce  fiscal  risk  and  improve  public  revenue  and 
expenditure management ensure that gender analysis is considered as part of decision-making 
and  creates  opportunities  to  support  women  entrepreneurs:  (i)  the  tax  reform  bill  minimizes 
disincentives for new and small businesses, including potential and existing women entrepreneurs, 
by moving to a more efficient and equitable net profits tax; (ii) the FY2020 fiscal review includes 
gender analysis of the impacts of cost-saving measures and gender-sensitive lessons for national 
budgets, particularly in light of COVID-19 impacts; and (iii) the MOF has approved an NIIP that 
includes processes to ensure that women’s needs and priorities are considered in the prioritization 
and selection of projects. Further measures to support gender equality outcomes will be pursued 
for subprogram 2, including the collection of sex-disaggregated data in PFM systems to support 
initial gender-responsive budgeting actions and through an electronic companies registry. 
 
32. 
Safeguards. Based on an evaluation of the potential impacts of supported policy actions, 
the  program  will  not  result  in  any  adverse  consequences  for  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement, or indigenous peoples. In line with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the 
program is classified category C for environment, involuntary settlement, and indigenous peoples.

Indicative Policy Actionsb 
(August 2021–July 2022) 

1.1. The President has transmitted to the 
OEK for approval a Bill for the national 
government’s FRA which includes 
provisionsc for managing public revenue, 
expenditure, debt, and fiscal buffers 
supporting fiscal sustainability to be 
reflected in Palau’s future annual 
national budgets.  

1.2. The President has issued a Directive 
for the implementation of Guidelines for 
preparing and updating an MTFS, 
applying a comprehensive and multi-year 
budgeting approach that better 
accommodates revenue volatilities while 
setting a clear fiscal policy direction, with 
procedures for updating as part of 
annual national budget preparation; and 
the Guidelines have been published for 
transparent fiscal governance. 
2.1. The President has transmitted a Tax 
Reform package—which (i) broadens the 
revenue base by replacing the general 
imports tax with a value-added tax that 
brings consumption of services into the 
tax net, (ii) eliminates distortions by 
moving from gross revenue taxation to a 
net profits tax and replacing import 
duties for alcohol and tobacco with an 
excise tax that also applies to local 
production, (iii) promotes equity by 
adjusting income thresholds for the 
wages and salaries tax and aligning the 
net profits tax with the highest marginal 
tax rates for wages and salaries, and 
(iv) includes actions to help remove 
barriers to businesses owned by women 
and reduce the cost of goods—to the 
OEK for approval. 
2.2. The MOF has implemented in 
FY2021, recommendations to reprioritize 
expenditures based on the FY2020 
Economic and Fiscal Review—a new 
annual budget execution evaluation 
mechanism that the government is 
implementing while COVID-19 impacts 
remain in place—which includes a 
comprehensive evaluation of COVID-19 
relief measures delivered during FY2020 
to assess their (i) efficiency, (ii) targeting, 
and (iii) cost effectiveness. 

1.1. The MOF shall have included an 
Economic and Fiscal Update to underpin 
the FY2022 national budget document, 
which provides an assessment of how 
the government’s fiscal program adheres 
to FRA provisionsc for strengthening 
management of public revenue, 
expenditure, debt, and fiscal buffers to 
support fiscal sustainability.  
1.2. The MOF shall have commenced 
implementation of the MTFS Guidelines 
by presenting as part of the FY2022 
national budget an MTFS calibrated to 
maintain appropriateness of policy 
directions to account for any changes in 
the economic landscape to safeguard 
fiscal sustainability. 
 

2.1. The MOF shall have established and 
operationalized a Tax Reform 
Committee, with at least 30% female 
members, to oversee a timebound plan 
for implementation of the Tax Reform 
package, including through the 
development of implementing rules and 
regulations and identification of systems 
upgrading and capacity building needs. 
 

2.2. The MOF shall have continued 
implementation of expenditure 
reprioritization measures in FY2022, 
further informed by the FY2021 
Economic and Fiscal Review that 
accounts for evolving COVID-19 impacts 
and identifies necessary adjustments to 
the delivery of relief measures to cost-
effectively address continuing needs. 

 2.3. The MOF has endorsed the NIIP, 
which supports the FRA principle of 
allocating adequate resources for capital 
expenditures in annual national budgets 
to ensure rising national net worth over 
time, while also providing for gender-
sensitive processes and climate-
resilience considerations for filtering, 
prioritization, and selection of projects to 
ensure that women’s needs for 
infrastructure services are adequately 
addressed.  
2.4. The President has transmitted the 
External Debt Management Bill—which 
specifies provisions for strengthening 
review of the fiscal and economic 
implications of any new borrowing, 
including through the creation of a debt 
management unit, while promoting debt 
transparency—to the OEK for approval.  
2.5. The MOF has endorsed an actuarial 
evaluation of the social security pension 
fund, to provide strong policy basis for 
reforms to restore sustainability in the 
long-term contribution–benefit ratio, 
particularly in the context of additional 
pressures stemming from the COVID-19 
crisis. 
3.1. The President has transmitted the 
International Arbitration Bill—which 
recognizes international arbitration of 
commercial disputes to encourage more 
foreign direct investment and boost 
business and employment opportunities 
in Palau—to the OEK for approval. 

3.2. The President has issued a Directive 
establishing an inter-agency technical 
working groupd to develop a Policy 
Statement for PPPs, which will provide 
formal guidance on the selection, 
monitoring, and regulation of the 
government’s private sector partners to 
improve the performance of SOEs and 
reduce their requirements for 
government transfers while expanding 
the tax base. 
3.3. The MOF has completed and 
endorsed a review of the corporations 
bill,e to provide strong policy basis for 
additional necessary provisions, 
including for the development of an 
electronic companies registry that 
supports increased transparency on 
beneficial ownership to increase tax 
compliance and reduce integrity risks.

implementation of the gender-sensitive 
NIIP starting with the FY2022 national 
budget, with allocation of capital budgets 
aligned with the NIIP’s objectives of 
raising national net worth over time while 
also supporting infrastructure services 
that specifically address women’s needs.  

2.4. The MOF shall have approved a 
Debt Management Policy, as per 
provisions of the External Debt 
Management Act, to strengthen 
transparency and oversight for any 
proposed public or publicly-guaranteed 
borrowing, toward ensuring positive 
returns to Palauan society as a whole. 
2.5. The President shall have transmitted 
a Social Security Reform Bill—with 
provisions to strengthen fiscal 
sustainability of the social security 
pension fund—to the OEK for approval. 
 

3.1. The President shall have signed the 
International Arbitration Bill into law, to 
provide an alternative, cost-effective, and 
time-efficient means of dispute resolution 
between parties in international 
commercial disputes; and the law shall 
have posted on the official website for 
Republic of Palau Public Laws to be 
freely accessible the public. 
3.2. The President shall have issued a 
Policy Statement for PPPs, filling a 
current regulatory gap and supporting 
more efficient and effective service 
delivery by government, SOEs, and 
private sector partners. 

3.3. The President shall have transmitted 
an updated Corporations Bill—which 
provides for streamlined and modern 
processes for applications and approvals 
of new companies toward reducing the

COVID-19 = coronavirus disease, FRA = fiscal responsibility act, FY = fiscal year, MOF = Ministry of Finance, MTFS = 
medium-term fiscal strategy, NIIP = national infrastructure investment plan, OEK = Olbiil Era Kelulau (Palau's national 
congress), PPP = public–private partnership, SOE = state-owned enterprise. 
Note: The fiscal year of the Government of Palau and its agencies ends on 30 September. “FY” before a calendar year 
denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2020 ends on 30 September 2020. 
a   All prior actions for subprogram 1 have been completed by the government.  
b  The triggers for subprogram 2 are indicative, and will be further refined based on government priorities and capacity, 

considering possible continued COVID-19 disruptions. 

c  The FRA provisions include: (i) maintaining operating expenditures within medium-term targets; (ii) managing capital 
spending to upgrade public assets over time; (iii) maintaining debt at prudent levels; (iv) preserving the real value of 
Compact Trust Fund by establishing investment and withdrawal rules; (v) adopting a modern and efficient tax regime 
suitable  for  a  tourism-based  economy;  (vi)  managing  reserves  as  insurance  coverage  for  cyclical  downturns, 
disasters, and climate change impacts; and (vii) managing fiscal risks from public sector entities, including SOEs and 
social security funds . 
 The Technical Working Group for Developing a Policy Statement for Public–Private Partnerships includes members 
from key divisions from the MOF and the Ministry of Public Infrastructure, Industries, and Commerce.  

d 

e  The  bill  was  first  introduced  in  the  OEK  in  2018  but  was  stalled  as  it  was  deemed  incomplete,  given  the  lack  of 
provisions for a modern companies registry. It also became outdated. The government sought development partner 
TA to complete the bill. The review, supported by ADB’s technical assistance, addresses the need for an electronic 
companies registry.
